comments.commentBody:
Bannon is bad news. He is a conspiracy theory guy, which is not what you want in the White House. Presidents need to run reality based administrations, and that is not Bannon's thing.

He is opposed by many very conservative people. If he is judged to be anti-semitic, that will upset some powerful Republican donors. The silence from elected Republicans almost certainly indicates that they deeply dislike the guy. Many conservatives think he is crazy.

The history of very controversial and offensive headlines at Breitbart makes Bannon a very very easy target for Trump's opponents to demonise. They will use his headlines to drive fundraising.

I think what Trump is trying to do is to balance Priebus with an figure who is critical of the Republican establishment. That is a smart idea, but Bannon is the wrong man for the job. Ann Coulter would be better, although she might also be too controversial.

Well, you all seem to have invented a new academic discipline: writing history before it happens. It's sure easier that way, isn't it?
Obama said it: "Elections have consequences. I won."
Trump won.
At least let him commit one of the crimes you have already convicted him of before punishing him.

Bannon wrote, “Let the grassroots turn on the hate because that’s the ONLY thing that will make [Republican leaders] do their duty.” And what duty is that?

That would be the duty to make America white again (Mr. Trump's dog whistle decoded). The duty Bannon speaks of is to oppress minorities of color in a white ruled America. Mr. Bannon wants the Republican Party to legislate his hate into law. He called for an outpouring of hate and that hate won the day. What Trump's election is doing is taking a dirty discarded needle and injecting Bannon's hate into America's arteries.

Hard to believe, but Bannon is actually more despicable than Trump. They both lack what makes mankind human, but Bannon is actually using Trump as a chump to spread his venom (ironic because Trump used so many Americans as chumps to buy his snake oil).

There's little difference between Bannon and previous GOP practitioners of hate, except he's more honest.

Nixon's Southern Strategy, Reagan's "welfare queen," Bush's Willie Horton, His son's phony "compassionate conservatism," McCain giving us Sarah Palin, and Romney's idea of "self-deportation."

I find Bannon's type refreshing: no smiling winks and nods, no sugar coating. He serves it strait up.

Let's not pretend he's an aberration. We built this!

Does sending a signal with Bannon imply that Trump has any particular aims in doing this? I ask, because I suspect that he gave Bannon and Priebus their positions because they've consistently kissed-up to him, not necessarily because they sit at any particular place along the left-right spectrum.

I mean, you can send a signal without that being you intention to do so. A facial tic might send the signal that someone has contempt for another person. Or a business might flout affirmative action laws simply in order to make money, but in doing so, it might indicate that it holds diversity or members of the group in question in low regard.

The churning emotions I have felt since last Tuesday rival those I have felt when people I loved throughout my life - like my parents and my sister - died. Something in America died last week.

But my emotions now include a seething contempt, not only for Donald Trump and the fascist Republican Party which made this all possible (sorry, but there is absolutely nothing separating the GOP - Paul Ryan included - from what Trump and Bannon represent; they are intertwined), but also contempt for those who voted for them, or did not vote, or voted for patently absurd third party alternatives like Jill Stein or Gary Johnson.

The grotesque ugliness of spirit represented by a white supremacist advocate like Bannon being part of Trump's inner circle speaks volumes about Trump and about Republicans, especially those craven Republicans who remain silent, members of the self-proclaimed "Party of Personal Responsibility"; representatives of the equally craven "values voters" who put them there.

Bannon's bad, not just for what he is, but for what he reveals to us about Trump. Trump is literally picking his cabinet from buddies he picked up in the past few months. He's not doing any real vetting or fact-finding. He doesn't even seem to have respected long-time friends to help guide him through these crucial moments.

So this is how his presidency will be. Lazy, slapdash, off-the-cuff evaluation of the most vital of issues. Over and over for the next four years. Unless he just abdicates his essential responsibilities altogether and lets his cadre make all the decisions. Either way, the world's in for a bumpy, horrifying ride.

The one consolation is that, broken-clock style, in some ways we might be better off with his off-the-cuff incompetence then with an actual evil mastermind deliberately decimating our democratic ideals. Let's hope "shut up Newt!" becomes a frequent refrain in the Trump White House.

Who you surround yourself with speaks volumes.  For those who say that Trump is not an ideologue and therefore he will in the end do what it more centrist and acceptable, look at who he is choosing to fill the slots and act as counsel.  He has a history of listening and reacting to the last person he has spoken to, so when he left the President's office he seemed open to certain changes to his avowed positions, as he had been given new information or had a greater understanding of more of the totality and reality of the situations he had expressed opposition to.   Unfortunately, I think he has already walked back some of what he said and thought at the time (I am not sure about my last statement), because he reunited with his "advisers." To everyone who keeps telling me to have an open mind and see where things go, I say my fears are being realized and my mind is already closing.

It's like "The Twilight Zone." President-elect Trump, who tore asunder the Republican Party, now says he wants to unite the country, which is more diverse than at any time in its history ... and as chief strategist he chooses Stephen Bannon. How can the president-elect say he's sorry for, among other sins, insulting women, blacks, Hispanics, Muslims, the disabled, and war veterans, when the man who will have first access to his ear runs a website that does most of that daily? He can't say he's sorry, and he won't, because he isn't and never will be.

Electing a capricious egomaniac Leader of the Free World was an act of inestimable stupidity. Donald Trump's inconstancy does not evince middle-ground political fluidity but ignorance and unprincipled demagoguery of a type never before seen at the pinnacle of American politics.

Take 10 minutes to read Breitbart News. Any reasonable American can clearly see the hate, racism and clear lies present in the articles. Read the comments and you find some of the most delusional and outright hateful commentary in the net. By any measure, Bannon should have no place in American politics let alone in the White House.
Has it really come to this? Debating whether Ann Coulter would be better than Bannon as chief adviser to the president? We are doomed.

Accurately describing someone's views is not inventing history -- it is calling Bannon what he is. Many Trump voters are likely decent people who genuinely feel marginalized economically and who were not aware of Bannon's beliefs. They need to know what they've bought.

I'm still amazed at how little Americans know and how little they pay attention. How can people NOT have heard of Breitbart, unless they've had their head in the sand for the last 16 years (the Alt Right has been around since Bush).

Wake up America! A Dictatorship is forming before your very sleepy eyes.

Are you kidding me? Our democracy is at risk and the free press must call it as it sees it. Racist demagoguery has no place in society and if this man continues to practice it he must be called out or impeached, whatever comes first.
There is a difference between campaigning and governing. Bannon is now helping to govern the nation.
Let's not treat Mr. Bannon like an outlier. This is who Mr. Trump and the Republican party are.

All those Trump supporters who protested or felt slighted that they were being labeled racist by liberal crybabies should either join in the protest now against Bannon or just admit they ARE racist. You keep giving Trump a pass on every horrible thing he says and does but there is a straight line between "Mexico sends its rapists" to picking Bannon as chief strategist. Trump keeps pushing the envelope, and right in front of our eyes he is dismantling the greatness of our country, and meanwhile his supporters see and hear nothing.

I feel like I fell into an alternate universe.
Anyone who thinks Trump is trying to "balance" Bannon with Priebus doesn't know either man. Bannon will eat Priebus for lunch.

Trump remains a dangerous fool. Bannon, on the other hand, isn't so much of an anti-Semite. He had no problem pocketing millions for repackaging "Seinfeld" reruns for syndication. But now that hating Jews is back in style thanks to Trump, Bannon is having his fifteen seconds of fame.

Willful ignorance, racism and third-hand hatred for the tremendous good Obama did for America, that's the Trump gift to America. No wonder Trump lost the popular vote by almost 700,000 votes. Trump does not belong in the White House, and knee-jerk hatred for our fellow citizens does not belong in the United States.
In any case, the loser is America.

This appointment is a victory for what this country fought against in WWII. How did this happen? The complete dumbing-down of America, its obsession with surfaces and gadgets, its elevation of celebrity and Roman-arena sports, its ahistorical complacency and self-serving prideful faux patriotism and the delusion that unbridled consumerism equals freedom. We have enjoyed something unprecedented: access to recorded history of revolution, totalitarianism fascism, the bomb...and we've chosen to ignore the harsh lessons of all those phenomena of the last century. It is shameful that this great country has squandered so much. Now we shall pay a huge price.

I am afraid. If you are not a person of color, not a Jew, not a female....it's no excuse. Close your eyes, use your imagination for just one second, imagine yourself as the other. We've all been taught that Americans are supposed to be better than this. If we don't show each other this, not to mention the rest of the world, then we are doomed.

Demand that the President-elect, who serves us, rescind these horrifying appointments now.

Segments of the Republican Party must be heaving a sigh of relief. They no longer have to pretend that they respect women and minority rights that they have opposed under the gauzy veil of religion, law and order, or tradition. Now they can just boldly spew hate, act like pigs and openly move to control the people whose movements toward freedom terrify them. These reactionaries' goal has always been to reassert control through fear and dominance because any one else's freedom is seen as limiting theirs.

Don't tell me that many of the people who voted for Trump weren't hoping for this. I am watch CBS now as I write this and the attempt to normalize Trump is going apace. His supporters are angry and this angry minority doesn't want any moderating. God help us all!

I'd imagine that it was Bannon who fed him the lines that got him elected.  I'd imagine he thinks more of what Bannon has to offer will keep him popular as president.  He might not yet understand that he's president of the whole now and not just his base.

New York Times writers and readers can fret to their (our) hearts' content. Only a small sub-community of Americans cares. The country has been bamboozled into electing what is little more than a troop of dyspeptic trolls.

It will take a long time, maybe four or eight years, to absorb the full meaning of the Trump debacle. The meaning of Trump himself and his "advisers" such as Stephen Bannon no longer hold much mystery. They telegraphed in advance clearly who they are. We voted for them anyway.

What continues to puzzle is what last Tuesday says about us. The mirror reflection of the USA looks ugly and frightening. We'll all be forced to look at this image for at least four years, after which there will be one mammoth mess to clean up.

www.endthemadnessnow.org

It is time for those who agree with Mr Bannon to own it. You have your man in a position of power, so come forth into the open.

Why do you hide if your cause is just? Why do you complain about the media if you are in the right? Why do you not name what you are by its true name?

Have the courage of your convictions, wear your cause on your sleeve. Many you target do not have the cption to hide. If your cause is just, you will reveal yourselves. Otherwise you are cowards.
